title: Fast and high-fidelity in situ 3D imaging protocol for stem cells and niche components for mouse organs and tissues
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Tissue cryoprotection
Timing: 30 min–2 h
In this step, embedding in water-soluble embedding medium and snap freezing in liquid nitrogen for tissue preservation is described.
Embedding in optimal cutting temperature compound (OCT).
Rinse the bones 2× with 10 mL PBS in 15 mL tubes to get rid of PFA solution.
Dry the bones with tissue; make sure that they are clean; if necessary, remove redundant tissue.
Fill the cryomolds with OCT until the upper limit.
Positioning of the tissue in OCT (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1741-Fig3.jpg
Figure 3. Embedding position of long bones
Embedding position of (A) femur, (B) tibia and (C) humerus in OCT.
Place the bones longitudinally close to the left side of the OCT containing cryomold.
Make sure the bones are fully immersed and parallel to the left edge of the cryomold (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]), to achieve the maximal frontal tissue surface after cryo-shaving.
Move bubbles out if they are formed.
Snap freezing in liquid nitrogen (LN2).
For dealing with LN2, wear protective equipment in appropriate rooms.
Grab the filled cryomold with long-armed tweezers with the help of a table surface (Figures 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]A and 4B).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1741-Fig4.jpg
Figure 4. Snap freezing in liquid nitrogen
(A) Grabbing the filled cryomold with long-armed tweezers.
(B) Side view of the cryomold with a table surface.
(C) Touching the bottom of the cryomold with the surface of the LN2.
(D) Freezing of the OCT (white) from bottom to top.
(E) Totally frozen OCT.
(F) Dropping the specimen into LN2.
Touch gently with the bottom of the cryomold the surface of the LN2 in an appropriate open LN2 Dewar flask. Attachment is ensured when a bubbling sound begins (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]C).
Critical: Too quick plunging of the sample into LN2 can cause formation of bubbles.

Let the OCT get freeze (white) from bottom to top (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]D).
When the OCT is totally frozen (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]E, drop it into the LN2 (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]F).
Critical: Fast snap freezing is essential to prevent formation of ice crystals which induce cellular and architectural tissue damage.
Critical: For long-term preservation (up to 5 years, see Figure 14[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig14]) frozen and embedded tissue should be stored subsequently at −80°C.
Cryostat shaving procedure
Timing: 20 min/tissue block
This section describes the cryostat shaving procedure of the specimen for obtaining optimal bisected bone whole-mounts for 3D confocal imaging.
Set up the cryostat settings according to the “materials and equipment[href=https://www.wicell.org#materials-and-equipment]” section.
Transfer the samples to dry ice to prevent OCT melting.
Freeze the frozen block on a specimen chuck on the long side using OCT and with the tissue upside down. If available, use a quick freeze chamber.
Critical: The chuck should be at 18°C–25°C prior to use to ensure optimal adhesion.
Allow time (5–10 min) for the temperatures within the cryostat to stabilize.
Start to shave the block with the trimming function until the bone marrow is maximally exposed. Also see Methods video S1[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc1].
Critical: To prevent severe damage, ensure that the blade does not crash into the sample.
Switch to the sectioning thickness and shave the specimen 10–20×. Also see Methods video S1[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc1].
Critical: To ensure a planar shaved surface, check during the shaving steps the blade for notches caused by the bone matrix. If notches occur, shift the blade to an undamaged part or use a new one (troubleshooting 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.3]). Be cautious during the shaving procedure as the blades are very sharp.
Note: Use a brush to remove debris from the sample.
Cut the frozen tissue block with a razor blade from the specimen chuck.

The shaved samples can be stored 3–4 weeks at −80°C prior to immunofluorescence staining.

Whole-mount immunostaining
Timing: 1–7 days
This section describes the immunostaining procedure to image 3D information of hematopoietic stem cells and niche components (vasculature, endosteum, megakaryocytes) throughout the whole femoral bone marrow section with optimized antibodies, which, in total, need 5 days. The incubation times and concentrations of the used antibodies in this protocol are the same for other appropriate tissues. Novel antibodies should be validated before use.
Purification from melting OCT.
Place the shaved and frozen samples into a box with separating chambers which are filled with ∼150 mL cold (4°C) washing buffer solution to cover the samples (Figures 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]A and 5B).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1741-Fig5.jpg
Figure 5. Purification from melting OCT
(A and B) Frozen samples in PBS.
(C) Melting samples.
(D) Washing samples with washing buffer solution.
Critical: Throughout the remaining parts of the protocol, avoid touching the exposed bone marrow to prevent losing cells and causing tissue artifacts (troubleshooting 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.3]).
Wait until the OCT around the sample is melted in the cold (4°C) washing buffer solution (Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]C).
After the OCT is melted (Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]C), take out the exposed samples cautiously with tweezers and wash the bones with washing buffer solution with a plastic bottle to get rid of sticky OCT (Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]D).
Critical: Don’t pour the washing solution directly to the exposed bone marrow to avoid causing artifacts.
Note: Use a see-saw rocker with ca. 30 rpm and cover the samples with a box from light for every step from now on.
Prepare 24-well plates (wp) for fixation and washing (Figure 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6]A) and 0.2 mL PCR tubes for blocking and antibody incubation (Figure 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6]B).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1741-Fig6.jpg

Figure 6. Washing and incubation equipment
(A) 24-wp for fixation and washing.
(B) 0.2 mL PCR tubes for blocking and antibody incubation.
Note: Solution amounts in 0.2 mL PCR tubes for blocking and antibody incubation for femur is 260 μL, for tibia 250 μL, for humerus and sternum 200 μL. In general, the processed tissue should be fully covered by the solution in the tube.
Fixation in 24-wp.
Fill one well for each sample with 2 mL 4% PFA fixation solution.
Place the bone samples into the fixation solution with the shaved surface, so that the BM doesn’t touch the bottom and incubate for 30 min at 18°C–25°C.
Wash the samples 3× 20 min at 18°C–25°C by relocating from well to well with each well containing 2 mL of washing buffer solution.
Place the samples in 0.2 mL PCR tubes with blocking and permeabilization buffer; incubate at 18°C–25°C for 1 h.
Primary hematopoietic lineage antibody staining (troubleshooting 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.5] and 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.7]):
Prepare the lineage antibody cocktail solution with biotinylated anti-CD41 (1:2500), anti-CD48 (1:100), anti-CD11b (1:100), anti-B220 (1:100), anti-CD5 (1:100), anti-Gr-1 (1:100), anti-Ter119 (1:100), anti-CD8a (1:100) in antibody diluent buffer.
Incubate at 4°C for 2 days.
Critical: Spin down the antibody vials to remove aggregates and precipitates to avoid the occurrence of non-specific fluorescent spots.
Wash the samples 3× 20 min at 18°C–25°C in washing buffer solution (troubleshooting 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.7]).
Secondary antibody staining (troubleshooting 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.5] and 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.7]):
Prepare secondary antibody solution with streptavidin (eFluor®450- or FITC- conjugated, 1:60) in antibody diluent buffer.
Incubate at 18°C–25°C for 2 h.
Wash the samples 3× 20 min at 18°C–25°C in washing buffer solution (troubleshooting 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.7]).
SLAM antibody staining (troubleshooting 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.5] and 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.7]):
Prepare antibody solution with anti-CD150-PE (4 μg/mL) in antibody diluent buffer.
Incubate at 4°C for 3 days.

Wash the samples 3× 20 min at 18°C–25°C in washing buffer solution.
Place the bone samples in 24-wp in storage buffer solution (2 mL per well) with the shaved surface and store at 4°C in the dark until microscopy.
Pause point: Samples can be imaged 1–3 days after the staining procedure.
Confocal microscopy
Timing: 0.5 days
This section describes the sample mounting and confocal 3D microscopy. Every immunostaining experiment has special settings and here we give the basic settings for 3D imaging we are using for the iFAST3D protocol.
Note: With many confocal microscope acquisition software you can retrieve settings from previous experiments.
Drop 30 μL–80 μL washing and storage buffer solution to the bottom glass of a 4-well-μ-slide (Figure 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig7]A) to prevent tissue desiccation.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1741-Fig7.jpg
Figure 7. Microscope glass chamber
(A) 4-well-μ-slide chamber with 60 μL washing and storage buffer solution.
(B and C) Placing of a whole-mounted sternum.
(D) View from the bottom side of the sample.
Place the fluorescently labeled tissue cut-face down onto the drop in the 4-well-μ-slide (Figures 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig7]B and 7C) and check from the bottom side that the sample surface is completely touching the glass planar (Figure 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig7]D).
Critical: Avoid too much pressure which can press out BM and prevent formation of air bubbles (troubleshooting 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.3] and 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.9]).
Cover the microscope glass chamber with the associated lid.
Switch on the confocal microscope system.
Place the glass chamber on the stage of the microscope.
Use a 10× objective for preview and choose a region for setting up in the widefield mode.
Set up the acquisition settings for confocal microscopy:
Set up the channel configurations based on the excision/emission parameters of the used fluorochromes and dyes in the staining.
Note: If available, use the auto-set-up mode with the ideal option.

Use transmitted light detection (DIC) for trabecular and cortical bone matrix detection and for structural details.
Use an image size resolution of 1024 × 1024 with bidirectional scanning (600 Hz–800 Hz) and 3–5× averaging.
Switch to a 20× objective and confocal live mode.
Optimize the detector parameters gain, laser power etc. by negative controls and/or by a software over-saturation option (troubleshooting 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.5] and 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.7]).
Critical: Avoid long-lasting laser exposure of the region of interest (ROI) to prevent photobleaching of sensitive types of labeled antibodies.
Scan for a ROI using 10× objective in the widefield mode.
Switch back to a 20× objective and confocal live mode.
Set up the z-stack configurations:
Set up the lower and upper focal plane scanning limits. A limit is reached when the image is out of focus. Z-thickness size can vary between 20 μm–75 μm.
For optimal and fast scanning, use a step size between 1.0 μm to 3.5 μm (z-step size).
Optional: Set start and stop points for z-stack tile scanning.
Start the scanning procedure for 3D imaging and save your z-stack data subsequently.
Processing and 3D visualization of raw data using Volocity analysis software
Timing: 30 min per image
This section describes how to import raw data, how to process images to visualize in 3D and how to export images by using Volocity software as an example. For 3D reconstruction and subsequent quantification and analysis of structural, cellular, and subcellular properties, also other image analysis platforms (e.g., Imaris, ImageJ, FIJI) can be used.
Note: Common file formats with metadata, generated by conventional confocal microscope systems, are supported and can be added to Volocity by drag and drop. The software saves every step automatically.
Import of raw images:
Go to the “File” menu and select “New Library…” (Figure 8[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig8]A).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1741-Fig8.jpg

Figure 8. Key steps for importing and loading raw images in Volocity
(A) “New Library…” selection in the “File” menu.
(B) “Library” view section.
(C) Image view modes.
Name the library and choose the destination for storage.
Drag the raw image, or folder with images, into the “Library” view on the left side of the screen (Figure 8[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig8]B).
Image sequences with the appropriate XYZ dimensions, channels and timepoints will be generated automatically.
Imported images can be viewed in different modes, like “3D Opacity”, “XYZ” and “Extended Focus” (Figure 8[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig8]C).
Note: We use the “Extended Focus” mode for fast screening of the images and enhancement of the signal intensity and brightness for individual channels.
3D visualization:
Select the image from the “Library” view for 3D visualization.
In the drop-down menu at the top of the screen, change the display option to “3D Opacity” (Figure 9[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig9]A).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1741-Fig9.jpg
Figure 9. Key steps for processing and 3D visualization and exporting images in Volocity
(A) Display option “3D Opacity”.
(B) Tools for change actions.
(C) Channel control slider.
(D) Rendering mode selection.
(E) “Image” menu with the “Display” submenu.
(F) “Capture Snapshot…” selection.
Use the tools at the top of the window to change actions for rotating and zooming for a required 3D view (Figure 9[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig9]B).
Optimize the brightness (recommended 1×–4×), density (recommended 50%) and the black level (recommended 2%–10%) for individual channels on the channel control view on the right side of the screen (Figure 9[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig9]C).
Choose from the channel control view the proper rendering “Mode” (Fluorescence, Isosurface, Max Intensity) for the best presentation of your data and observations (Figure 9[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig9]D).
To show a scale bar and the XYZ-orientation on the image, go to the “Image” menu, the “Display” menu and select “Show Scale” and “Show Orientation” (Figure 9[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig9]E).
Export of 3D visualized images:

To create a single image illustration of the current 3D view, go to the “Image” menu and select “Capture Snapshot…” (Figure 9[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig9]F).
A snapshot image is added at the bottom of the library list.
Select the snapshot image from the library list and in the “File” menu choose “Export…”.
The snapshot of the 3D visualization can now be exported in any supported file format (e.g., TIFF, BMP, JPEG).
